awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Determining the eco-hydrogeologic response of tropical glacierized watersheds to climate change: An integrated data-model approach
awd_abstract_narration:
Recent rapid glacier retreat, especially in tropical regions such as the Ecuadorian Andes, raises important questions about water resources.  Understanding the current effects of glacier retreat on water supply in these regions can shed light on future water security threats in snow and ice-covered mountainous watersheds worldwide.  Glaciers are the "water towers" of the mountains: they store ice during wet periods and gradually release meltwater during dry periods. However, whether groundwater aquifers serve as extended reservoirs and whether plants also take up significant glacial meltwater remain unresolved questions.  These uncertainties make it difficult to predict the future reliability of water supply in mountainous watersheds, as glacier melt first accelerates and then eventually disappears, and as plants move to higher elevations in response to warming temperatures.  This project will develop a new and general computational watershed model that will incorporate chemical and isotopic data for tracing water flow source regions, as well as measurements from innovative low-cost, open-source environmental monitoring technologies. Results from the model can inform communities that rely on stream discharge from ice and snow-covered mountainous watersheds about present with regard to future water resources vulnerabilities, and can facilitate adaptation strategies as glacier retreat accelerates. 

	The recession of glaciers will curtail their ability to modulate river discharge and its variability. Studies of this hydrologic consequence typically classify meltwater and groundwater as distinct contributors to streamflow, but this oversimplifies the potentially complex relationships among glaciers, their underlying groundwater systems, and ecohydrologic pathways. The investigators propose to assess these relationships using an integrated data-model approach in four rapidly changing, glacierized Ecuadorian watersheds, two each at Volcán Chimborazo and Volcán Cayambe. This work will produce a new isotope-enabled watershed model with reactive transport, to which data assimilation will be introduced in order to condition uncertain simulations in data-sparse watersheds with robust environmental tracers.  Open-source data loggers and sensors for measuring model input data will further advance critical-zone process understanding beyond data-intensive sites to remote settings that are undergoing some of the most rapid environmental change in the world.  This work will shed light on less-studied volcanic ranges that potentially facilitate greater infiltration of meltwater through their fractured bedrock, as well as expand the established water-resources focus on glacier retreat to also consider vegetation shift when examining the hydrologic response of glacierized mountainous watersheds to glacier retreat.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Compared to our knowledge of mid-to-high latitudes, concerningly few studies examine watershed responses to glacier retreat in the tropics, where glaciers already undergo year-round net ablation and are thus highly vulnerable to climate change. Of the glacier studies that have emerged from the tropics, most focused solely on hydrological conditions and examined the outer tropics. To fill this critical knowledge gap, this project addressed glacierized watersheds in the Andean inner tropics, where glaciers experience a unique climate with subtle seasonal trends, occupy volcanoes with highly fractured and weatherable bedrock, and are perched above sensitive páramo ecosystems that are rapidly shifting with climate change. This complex setting demands an integrative investigation of how climate, glaciers, geologic setting, vegetation, and geochemical processes together control recent and future water quantity and quality. Understanding changes within vulnerable glacierized watersheds in the inner tropics is vital for the agrarian and urban communities reliant on these systems for their water supply, and these watersheds provide a window into potential changes to come in higher-latitude environments.

To address the extreme data sparsity on remote, inner tropical glaciers, we developed new open-source data loggers and sensors to track ablation, leveraged satellite and UAS remote sensing to generate estimates of glacier area change in Ecuador between 2001 and 2020, as well as current glacier volume and thickness throughout the northern Andes. Over that 20-year period, the total glacier surface area in Ecuador decreased by ~35% and now stands at 53.3 +/- 2.4 km sq. We combined our integrated watershed model with hydrochemical tracer data from a sub-humid watershed on Volcán Chimborazo in Ecuador to generate one of the first estimates of glacier-melt contributions to streams in the inner tropics. Model simulations showed that glacier melt contributes 20–60% of the total stream discharge and drives temporal variability in streamflow. This contrasts with higher-latitude glacierized settings where glacier melt generally smooths discharge variability by offsetting seasonal rainfall inputs. The watershed model further allowed us to probe traditionally ignored subsurface processes. In addition to finding that the fractured volcanic bedrock and moraine sediments contribute groundwater that constitutes 40–80% of total stream discharge, we determined that 18–37% of the groundwater is glacier-sourced. With this tight glacier–groundwater coupling, there may be limited potential for groundwater to sustain water supply in the inner tropics after the glaciers retreat. Model scenario tests further indicated that, without glacier melt and with increased air temperature, discharge at our Chimborazo study site could drop by 58%. This decline could be further exacerbated to a 74–78% drop as vegetation shifts upslope with climate change, highlighting the importance of considering ecohydrological interactions. With its powerful capability of representing geochemical reactions, our watershed model also showed that in a future without glacier melt, the concentration of major solutes (e.g., sodium and calcium) at our Chimborazo site will likely increase as the volume of water for dilution attenuates, possibly impairing drinking water quality. In contrast, solute export (the total mass leaving the watershed) will decrease by 23% because of less water to weather the volcanic bedrock and soils, and this could serve to limit nutrient delivery to downstream ecosystems. At a second study site in a humid watershed on Volcán Cayambe in Ecuador, hydrothermal spring waters released just below the glacier tongue obscure downgradient inorganic hydrochemical inputs, motivating the collection of dissolved organic matter (DOM) fluorescence data as an additional tracer to disentangle water sources. This has been among the first efforts in tropical glacierized mountains to characterize the DOM pool as water flows through a watershed, and distinct carbon signatures have emerged from different parts of the watershed. 

Striving for our project to tangibly benefit the Indigenous Kichwa communities living directly below our Cayambe study site, we led an art project that teaches about the water cycle on glacierized mountains with about 175 elementary school students at five local schools. Acknowledging data sovereignty, we also presented data tables to community leaders, and we discussed our findings about water quantity and quality trends with members of the five communities comprising the Corporación de Organizaciones Campesinas e Indígenas Juan Montalvo on Cayambe.
